title: What would happen or look like to humans if a 100km asteroid passed by the Earth at a distance of approximately 1000km? - Quora

response.answer_text: That would be an asteroid like lutitia…  … A 100km object 1000km away would have an angular size of 5.7deg This is the same size as a tennis ball viewed at arms length (63cm)… that is about 11 times the size of the Moon. You’d notice. You could use that picture (above) on your screen and stand back until you got the right angular resolution. Zoom until it is about tennis ball size and lean back in the chair… gives you an idea what you’d see. Note: guessing you mean 1000km overhead, and not 1000km from the center of the Earth… because the latter means everyone died (diameter of the Earth?) This object would likely have been spotted months out, and such a close approach is indistinguishable from an impact prediction… so everyone has been panicking for months by the time it passes so close. In astronomical terms that is very very very close. By the same week though, probably know it will likely miss so asteroid parties folks. The whole planets spends the rest of the year drunk.

A 100 km object at 1000 km distance would look as big as your fist held at arm’s length, or more than ten times as big as the Moon, directly under the point of closest approach. 3600 km away from that point on the Earth’s surface, the asteroid would be touching the horizon, and would appear to be only three times bigger than the Moon. As the asteroid approached and receded, it would appear smaller, but more people would be able to see it. At around 10,000 km from closest approach it will be as big as the Moon. At about the same distance as the Moon it would appear to be about the size of Tycho crater, I estimate, so even in the daytime it would be visible quite a ways out. At night, it’s quite likely to be a bright naked-eye object millions of km away, and would have been spotted through telescopes by astronomers if it was part of the asteroid belt or at a similar distance for at least a couple of centuries. If it came from outside the Solar System, it is quite likely that it would be spotted weeks, if not years, away because of its size. (‘Oumuamua is only a kilometre long on its longest axis and was very difficult to spot.)

TLDR; It would look pretty damn scary. A quick mental calculation suggests that at this distance the asteroid will have an angular width of 0.1 radian or about 5.7°. This is huge compared to the size of the moon which is about half a degree. So, if a 100km asteroid ever passes by so close to the earth, it will look like a fast moving giant supermoon.

If the closest approach happens during the day we may well not see the asteroid, particularly if there’s cloud cover. If we’re very lucky it may eclipse the sun and we will get a total eclipse. Apparent motion will be very fast. At night, we likely won’t see it at all when it’s in Earth’s shadow, though we will notice it eclipsing stars, planets, even the Moon; otherwise it will be bigger and brighter than the moon for a while (depending on the velocity).

That's not enough data to give a better answer than the “scary” one already given. Without knowing its mass or velocity we can’t really predict the outcome. A super light super fast asteroid would be very different from a super heavy slow one. Thats also ignoring what happens to it even if passes earth safely. If it smacks into the moon instead that would almost be worse.
